abstract.p: A procedure to design a composite tube that matches the flexural stiffness, load-carrying capacity, and energy absorption of an aluminum tube while subjected to bending load is of interest. The large deformation and energy absorption requirements are fulfilled through the progressive failure of the plies of suitable fiber orientations across the thickness of the tube. The layer wise nature of the composite tubes and cylindrical anisotropy, however, has impeded obtaining a simple closed-form solution for calculating the flexural stiffness. Available analytical solutions are mainly a complex set of equations, which should be solved simultaneously. In addition, the boundary and interface conditions between the adjacent plies must be satisfied. This article presents a straightforward simulation technique for this purpose. First, the tube is correlated to a corresponding composite sandwich panel, the flexural stiffness of which is obtained by the classical laminate theory. Then an analogous aluminum sandwich panel is designed and is correlated to a so-called ‘equivalent’ aluminum tube. The bending stiffness of the composite tube is shown to be the same as that of its equivalent aluminum tube. As a result, a complex problem of cylindrical anisotropy is mapped into a Cartesian coordinate system and solved via the classical laminate theory. The accuracy of the technique is verified by experimental work and analytical solutions. The agreement between the three methods is shown.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The advent of the Boeing 787 and Airbus 380 has caused a quantum leap in the use of composites in aerospace industry and given a great impetus for further consideration of these materials in primary load-bearing structures. One such application is that of the cross-piece for helicopter landing gear. The aluminum cross-tube of a typical medium-size helicopter has an inside diameter of 56 mm, an approximate length of 1.5 m and varying thicknesses from 16 mm, at the attachment to the compartment, to 4 mm, at the junction of the skid tubes. In a severe landing, the cross-piece shall support dynamic loads in the vicinity of 100 kN. In such circumstances, the aluminum cross-tube may deform plastically, at least in certain areas, to absorb and dissipate maximum possible crash energy and reduce the transferred shock loads to the fuselage.1

A composite tube having similar dimensions should involve up to 160 plies laid up in appropriate directions to achieve similar flexural stiffness and support the same load. However, composite structures due to the brittle nature of the fibers do not demonstrate plastic deformation, and therefore the energy absorption of a composite cross-piece will be considerably lower than that of the aluminum landing gear. This is detrimental to the design and safety of the passengers, and such composite landing gear may not pass the rotorcraft crashworthiness requirements.

Carbon fiber reinforced plastics (CFRPs) are currently the dominant composite materials in aerospace industry due to their high specific strength and stiffness and weight saving promises. However, the high specific properties are accompanied by inherent brittleness and low fracture strain of the material. Unidirectional CFRP laminates usually have a strain limit lower than 1.45% along the fiber direction, which is not sufficient to provide similar deformation as the aluminum cross-tube. As the fiber angle increases from zero degree toward 45°, the fracture strain of the laminate increases in the cost of sharp reduction in strength and stiffness. In addition, interlaminar stresses may develop between the layers, giving rise to early failure. These are challenges that have deterred applications of composites into such primary structures.

In spite of these, the authors have developed a generic stacking sequence that enables a composite tube to match the flexural stiffness, load-bearing capability and energy absorption of a target aluminum tube via strategic location of the plies across the thickness.2,3 Such tubes are called equivalent in this study. The equivalency in energy absorption imposes two conditions on the composite tube. First, it should carry the same load as its equivalent aluminum tube at the same deformation. Second, both tubes should have the same strain to failure requirements for a given application. For example, an equivalent composite cross-tube should have the same flexural stiffness as the aluminum cross-piece to assure similar rate of shock load transfer to the fuselage during a normal landing. A composite tube with higher flexural stiffness will transfer higher shock loads to the fuselage and therefore fails the first requirement. This article addresses this challenge by providing a straightforward methodology for calculating the flexural stiffness of tubular composite structures. On the other hand in a severe landing, the aluminum cross-tube may experience up to 2.5% plastic strain to absorb and dissipate maximum possible energy so that the safety of the passengers is intact. A composite tube with a small fracture strain will lose its integrity in a harsh landing, and it is not considered a design alternative. This challenge was overcome through proposing a generic layup that provides progressive failure.2

Several researchers have endeavored to obtain a closed-form solution for the flexural stiffness of composite tubes. Most of these efforts are based on the theory of elasticity for anisotropic bodies in the cylindrical coordinate system developed by Lekhnitskii.4 Composite tubes are considered a special case of anisotropy. Each layer is analyzed first and then the interfacial continuity and boundary conditions are satisfied.5,6 Although such methods can be straightforward, when many layers are involved, the system of equations will be large and many constants need to be determined. Alternatively, one may derive the governing equations in terms of displacements. However, the stress functions will be more complex.7,8 The authors also used the three-dimensional laminate theory and obtained an analytical solution for the flexural stiffness of composite tubes,9 which will be used as the reference in this article for comparison purposes.

The common drawback of these analytical solutions is the complexity of the models, which compels the users to deal with multiple sets of equations. Here, a simulation technique is proposed that correlates the flexural stiffness of a composite tube with those of its ‘corresponding’ composite and aluminum sandwich panels. The latter is then correlated to an ‘equivalent’ aluminum tube, the flexural stiffness of which can be easily determined. It will be shown that the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is equal to that of the ‘equivalent’ aluminum tube.

If this can be shown, the design and analysis of composite tubes will be considerably simplified, and the analysis time and the associated engineering costs can be reduced. For this purpose, three composite tubes with different dimensions and layups are considered. The flexural stiffness of each tube is calculated by the simulation technique and the analytical solution. The tubes are manufactured by automated fiber placement and tested in three or four bending. The experimental values for the flexural stiffness of the tubes are back calculated from the force–strain curves obtained from the tests. The agreement between the results is shown.

Moreover, the tubes are loaded beyond their elastic limits to study the effects of the layup on bending behavior of composite beams. In fact, the layup for one of these tubes is based on the proposed generic layup by the authors for large deformation capability [2]; therefore, it will be of interest to demonstrate the improvements over ordinary designs. A summary of the work to obtain the generic layup is presented here for the convenience of the reader.

sec.title: Strain-controlled design and the generic layup
sec.p: In the development of a high performance composite tube for applications such as the cross-piece of rotorcraft landing gear, deformation of the cross-tube is of critical importance. In the event of a severe landing, the cross-tube has to exhibit plastic deformation to minimize shock load transfer to the passenger compartment. While composites can offer light weight, high stiffness and high strength, their relative brittleness and abrupt failure can be a deterrent in this application. For composite materials, the matrix and the fiber orientation contribute to the fracture strain of the laminate. Recent developments in manufacturing toughened epoxies and high toughness thermoplastic polymers such as PEKK are all indicators of a genuine need for a less brittle and more reliable composite product in the market.

Carbon fibers are the dominant reinforcement constituent of composites for aerospace applications. For the purpose of this study, carbon fiber AS4/PEKK thermoplastic composite was considered. In comparison to conspicuous PEEK, polyether ketone ketone (PEKK) has higher glass transition temperature (156°C vs. 143°C) and lower processing temperature (340°C vs. 390°C). This has made PEKK competitive, in terms of mechanical properties, and cost effective due to the lower processing temperature. Meanwhile similar to PEEK, PEKK has excellent environmental resistance, high toughness and good bonding and painting characteristics.

Several flat laminates with different layups were made. From each panel five specimens were cut and loaded to fracture in tension per ASTM D3039. Figure 1 shows the stress–strain curves for a few laminates of this study. It can be seen that unidirectional laminates exhibit relatively low deformation while [±45°]2s laminates show no sign of brittle fracture. Also shown in the figure is the stress–strain response of an aluminum alloy for comparison. The following highlights of this study are noteworthy:
As the fiber angle changes from 0° to 45°, the strain limit increases. The strain limit for samples of [0°]4s is 1.45%, while that of the [±45°]2s samples is more than 6%. This comes with a sacrifice in the stiffness. The stiffness of the 0° laminates is much more than that of the ±45° laminates (140 GPa vs. 18 GPa).
The [±45°]2s laminates show the maximum strain limit as compared to other configuration of layups and ply angles (between 6% and 10%).
Adding pure resin layer between the composite layers helps improve the strain limit by reducing the interaction of adjacent layers, but the strength and stiffness of the laminate are reduced. This is evidenced by comparing the performances of the [±30°]2s samples with that of the [30°/resin/−30°/resin]2s samples. The [±30°]2s samples show a strain limit of 2.5% while the [30°/resin/−30°/resin]2s samples show a strain limit of 4.5%. Again, this comes with a sacrifice in stiffness.
Coupling layers of high strain limit together with layers of lower strain limit results in layers with lower strain limit being dominant in controlling the strain limit of the laminate. This is illustrated by the performance of the [90°/(±45°)3/0°]s samples and the quasi-isotropic [0°/90°/45°/−45°]s samples. Among the constituents of these samples, the [0°] layers show a strain limit of 1.45%, the [90°] layers show a strain limit of 0.8% while the [±45°] layers show a strain limit of 6%. When these are coupled together, the [90°/(±45°)3/0]s samples show a strain limit of 2% while the quasi-isotropic samples show a strain limit of 1.5%. In the quasi-isotropic laminates, the 0° layers dominate the failure strain. The strain limit of the laminate is the same as that of the 0° layers. Because of its high stiffness, the 0° layers bear almost if not all of the load until its failure. When the 0° layers load is transferred suddenly to the [±45°] layers, even though the [±45°] layers have higher deformability and strain limit, the sudden load transfer induces fast rate loading on these layers and they also fail. This can be termed as the domino effect. Adding more [±45°] plies to make the [90°/(±45°)3/0°]s laminate helps to improve the strain limit (from 1.5% to 2%) but the laminate cannot reach the maximum strain limit of the [±45°] layers.
In order to utilize the strain limit of the [±45°] layers more fully, one may want to separate the 0° layers from the [±45°] layers. This may be done by placing the 90° layers in-between the 0° and [±45°] layers.
Despite the small fracture strain of 0° plies, angle ply laminates show larger strain limits, which can be used to advantage. It is important to decouple layers of small strain limit from layers of higher strain limits to avoid the coupling effect where layers of small strain limit can be more dominant.

sec.title: Stiffness analysis
sec.p: Among analytical approaches employed to calculate the flexural stiffness of composite tubes, the authors used the nonclassical laminate theory and proposed a closed-form solution, which is cited here as reference. The ‘simulation technique’, presented hereinafter, is a novel methodology for calculating the bending stiffness of composite tube that is based on five clear-cut steps.

sec.title: Simulation method for stiffness calculation
sec.p: The simulation technique exploits the ease of structural analysis for isotropic materials over layer-wise composites. Here, the flexural stiffness of a composite tube is of interest. If the tube can be correlated to an ‘equivalent’ aluminum tube based on the similarity in flexural stiffness, then it would be sufficient to obtain the flexural stiffness of the aluminum tube via Equation (3) and assume that it would be the same for the composite tube. However, showing the equivalency of the tubes is as complex. The simulation technique proposes to simulate the tubes with their ‘corresponding’ sandwich panels and demonstrate the equivalency amongst the panels rather than the tubes. As such, a problem of cylindrical anisotropy may be reduced to a problem of classical laminate theory, which is considerably more convenient to address.

Figure 2 illustrates a procedure to obtain the ‘corresponding’ sandwich panels. The ‘corresponding’ composite sandwich panel shall have exactly the same skin thickness and layup as the wall of the composite tube, and its core thickness should be equal to ID of the tube. The width of the sandwich panel, however, can be assumed as the unit of width. This assumption stipulates that the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is proportional and not equal to that of the sandwich panel. However, it will be shown that as long as both aluminum and composite panels have the same width, this proportional factor has absolutely no effects on the analysis, and there is no need to assume any special value including 2πR. Figure 2.
Composite and aluminum tubes simulated with their corresponding sandwich panels.

Once its specifications are obtained, the composite sandwich panel can be analyzed as a solid laminate by considering its core as a symmetrical layer around the midplane. However, as the inside of the composite tube is not filled with a core, the mechanical properties of the core layer shall be set to zero in the analysis to prevent any contributions of the core in the flexural stiffness of the panel. The hypothetical location of the core layer, however, enables the other plies to be located at the right distances from the midplane, which should be equal to the distance of each ply from the center of the tube. Using the classical laminate theory, the flexural stiffness of the composite sandwich panel is calculated. The next step is to design an aluminum sandwich panel that matches this stiffness.

It is assumed that the aluminum panel has the same core material and dimensions as the composite panel. So, by setting an equality relationship between the flexural stiffness of the aluminum and composite panels, the skin thickness of the aluminum panel is calculated. The final step is to obtain the dimensions of the equivalent aluminum tube from those of the aluminum panel. The simulation technique suggests that the inner diameter of the tube is equal to ID and its wall thickness is equal to the skin thickness of the aluminum panel.

The above description of the method can be summarized in the following five steps:
Design the corresponding composite sandwich panel

As shown in Figure 2, a composite tube with inner diameter ID and outer diameter ID + 2H is considered. The tube can have any arbitrary layup such as [±θ1/±θ2/…/±θn]. The specifications of the corresponding composite sandwich panel shall be obtained from those of the composite tube as follows:

sec.title: Examples
sec.p:
Three composite tubes were manufactured using Automated Fiber Placement technique at the National Research Council of Canada, NRC-AMTC. The material was provided by Cytec Engineered Materials in the form of 6 mm wide slit tape. The maximum applied force and temperature were 450 N and 600°C, respectively. The required temperature in AFP process is higher than the normal processing temperature of the prepreg using compression molding technique because the hot nitrogen gas is only applied on the prepreg for a very short time. The material may literally experience temperatures around 350°C in average while the process of melting, consolidation and solidification occurs in just a few seconds. Example 1 shows a tube with cross-ply sequence. This is the simplest layup for a carbon fiber composite that is required to have an elastic modulus equal to that of aluminum in two perpendicular directions. This tube is tested in four-point bending. Example 2 shows a case where not only the requirements of stiffness are satisfied but also some provisions are considered to improve the deformability of the tube or at least avoid abrupt fracture. Example 3 shows the case of an optimized configuration where all stiffness, strength and deformation considerations are addressed. The last two tubes are tested in three-point bending. The corresponding force–strain curves are obtained. The axial strain is measured at the mid-length of the tubes on the bottom line. The results are compared with the force–strain curves of the reference aluminum tubes obtained from the elastic-plastic analysis. Comparison of the slopes for the force–strain curves of the composite and aluminum tubes in the elastic region indicates the applicability of the simulation technique in calculating the flexural stiffness of the layer wise composite tubes.

The reference tubes are made of aluminum 6061-T651 alloy. The material is modeled by Ramberg–Osgood equation, so the plastic hardening behavior of the material is also considered. It is assumed that the plastic deformation starts at the mid-length of the tube on the bottom and top lines where the maximum stresses due to bending moment will take place. The plastic zone expands in a symmetrical fashion around the mid-length and expands through the thickness as the bending moment is increased. According to the mechanics of materials, for a tube subjected to bending, the flexural stiffness can be calculated as: (12)1ρ=M〈EI〉 → ɛz=yρ=My〈EI〉 → 〈EI〉=Myɛz where z is the longitudinal axis, ɛz is the axial strain on the bottom line of the tube at the midsection, M is the bending moment, and y is the distance from neutral axis. For a tube with the length of L, outer radius of Ro, and three-point bending test setup, Equation (12) results in: (13)ɛz=Mr〈EI〉=PLr4〈EI〉 → 〈EI〉=PLRo4ɛzmax

The force–strain curve for a metallic or composite beam subjected to bending is linear in the elastic limit. Therefore, in all examples, the bending moments corresponding to 0.25% strain are obtained from the force–strain curves, and the flexural stiffness of the tubes are back-calculated using Equation (12). This strain value is well within the elastic limits of all the three examples.

sec.title: Example 1: The normal cross-ply [90°/0°]n
sec.p: Step 1. Layup sequence:

The first example is a composite tube with cross-ply layup sequence. The 0° plies will provide the strength and stiffness in the longitudinal direction, and 90° plies will reinforce the tube in the hoop direction and resist the radial and circumferential stresses. The tube aims to match the flexural stiffness of an aluminum (E = 70 GPa) tube with inner and outer diameters of 56.2 and 64.2 mm, respectively, which is about 24,000 N.m2 by Equation (3). Such tube weighs about 2 kg/m.

As shown in Table 1, the average modulus values in the fiber and transverse directions are about 140 and 10 GPa, respectively. The extensional stiffness of a cross-ply laminate is approximately an average of the two, 75 GPa, which is in fact very close to the Young’s modulus of aluminum. Therefore, a cross-ply composite tube with similar dimensions as the aluminum tube (ID 56.2 mm and OD 64.2 mm) should easily match and even exceed the flexural stiffness of the aluminum tube. As the solidified thickness of carbon AS4/PEKK unidirectional prepreg is 0.1 mm, a total of 40 plies will be necessary to build up the thickness.

In the composite beam design philosophy, normally the high-stiffness-high-strength materials are placed at the furthest distance from the neutral axis to provide the maximum flexural stiffness and bear the maximum load. Therefore, the normal way of thinking would be to use 0° plies as the outer layer and 90° plies as the liner. From the manufacturing point of view, placing 90° plies on the inside facilitates manufacturing and builds up a platform for placing unidirectional plies parallel to the tube generator as the outer layer. As such, the [90°20/0°20] layup sequence was considered. Such composite tube weighs about 1.1 kg/m that shows about 46% weight saving in comparison to the reference aluminum tube.

sec.title: Step 2. Stiffness matching:
sec.p:
Figure 3 illustrates the application of the simulation technique to calculate the flexural stiffness of the composite tube. First the corresponding composite sandwich panel is designed. The panel should have a hypothetical core thickness of 56.2 mm and 40 plies of skin laid up in [90°20/0°20] sequence to simulate the composite tube. Using the CLT, the flexural stiffness of the panel is obtained to be 549 N.m2. An aluminum sandwich panel with similar core dimensions and properties should have a minimum of 4.28 mm skin thickness to match the flexural stiffness of the composite panel. Therefore, the ‘equivalent’ aluminum tube should have an inner diameter of 56.2 mm and a wall thickness of 4.28 mm, which results in an outer diameter of 64.76 mm. According to the simulation technique, the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is equal to that of this equivalent aluminum tube, which is 26157 N.m2. This shows that the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is slightly more than that of the reference aluminum tube (ID 56.2 mm and OD 64.2 mm, EI 24000 N.m2). Therefore, for the experimental purposes, it is expected to see slightly higher slope in the force–deflection curve of the composite tube than that of the aluminum tube. Figure 3.
Application of the simulation technique for Example 1.

Table 2 compares the flexural stiffness of the reference aluminum tube using Equations (2) and (3) and those of the composite tube using the non-classical laminate theory and the simulation method. It can be seen that the difference for the stiffness of the aluminum tube using Equations (2) and (3) is about 0.3%. The difference between the calculated flexural stiffness of the composite tube by the simulation technique and the analytical solution is less than 1.2%. Table 2.

sec.title: Step 3. Experimental results:
sec.p: The performance of the proposed layup was evaluated by manufacturing a carbon AS4/PEKK thermoplastic composite tube with the layup sequence of [90°20/0°20] and testing the tube in four-point bending. The tube was reinforced by a few layers of fiberglass epoxy composite at the supports and at the loading points to avoid premature failure of the tube due to the inevitable stress concentration. The strain gages were installed at the mid-length of the tube both in the axial and circumferential directions on the top and bottom lines. The supporting span was 890 mm and the loading noses were 300 mm apart around the midsection of the tube.

The tube was loaded in the displacement-controlled method at the rate of 1 mm/min. Figure 4 shows the test set up at a final stage. Figure 5 shows the force–strain curve for the composite and reference aluminum tubes. The horizontal axis shows the axial strain at the midsection of the tube on the bottom line. It can be seen that the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is about 9% more than that of the aluminum tube, which is consistent with Table 2. Figure 4.
First tube under four-point bending. Figure 5.
Force–strain curves for the first composite and aluminum tubes.

Beyond first ply failure, the composite tube showed an abrupt fracture at the loading noses at about 20 kN bending load. The force carried by the tube sharply dropped. The maximum axial strain at the midsection did not exceed 0.55%. At this point, the tube broke into three straight pieces with no curvature. This indicated that the tube released the stresses, and the load-carrying capability of the tube had reduced to zero. The displacement measured beyond this point by the MTS machine was simply a rigid body motion of the broken pieces hold together by the lower section of the tube. Table 1 shows that the 0° plies have lower strength and stiffness in compression than in tension. Obviously, this has caused the fracture to initiate in compression zone on the upper half of the tube. Before fracture, the behavior of the tube was completely elastic. The acoustic emission sensor measurement device, installed on the back side of the tube, did not receive any pulse due to potential internal fractures and the axial and circumferential strains on the top line (in compression) were similar to those of the bottom line (in tension). Figure 5 also shows the limited deformation of the composite tube in comparison to the aluminum tube. The compression strength of carbon AS4/PEKK in the fiber direction is at least five times that of the aluminum 6061-T651. However, the higher strength was subverted by low fracture strain of the 0° plies in compression.

From the above observations, it can be concluded that even though [90°n/0°n] laminates have many applications in the form of flat plates and curved shells, in tubular form premature failure may occur due to the lower fracture strain and higher potentials of delamination. Angle-ply laminates such as ± 25° may be more suitable than 0° plies for a tubular structure as winding around the generator of the tube can contribute to circumferential strength and flexural stiffness simultaneously.

sec.title: Example 2: Cross-ply layup with additional ±45° external jacket
Step 1. Layup sequence:
sec.p: In Example 1, it was observed that a composite tube with combination of 0° and 90° layers may show the same stiffness as its equivalent aluminum tube under bending. However, the composite tube showed abrupt fracture. More efforts need to be done to improve this performance. Figure 1 shows that [+45°/−45°]2s laminate has the highest fracture strain (more than 6%) among all other layups. As such, including ±45° plies in the design of the layup sequence should improve the deformability of the tube. Two characteristics are involved. First, when zero degree layers fail at about 1% or lower, the ±45° laminate has more room for deformation. As such, upon fracture of zero degree layers, even though there might be a sharp reduction in load level to some extent, some load shall be transferred from 0° layers to ±45° layers, and the load-carrying capacity of the tube should not reduce to zero as per Example 1. If no domino effect occurs, it is expected that the tube would continue to carry some load at a reduced level and show higher strains due to the deformation of ±45° plies. Furthermore, if a jacket of ±45° plies forms the outer layer of the tube, the composite tube can keep its integrity even after the fracture of inner 0° layers. The external 45° plies and the internal 90° plies can confine the movement of the 0° plies in the middle so that they will carry some loads after fracture by pressing the broken fibers against each other in the compression zone until a fracture occurs in the tension zone.

Meanwhile, one cannot use only ±45° plies to build up the required thickness because such layup has very low strength and stiffness, so the composite tube would be extremely thick in comparison to its equivalent aluminum tube. Therefore the 0° and 90° layers are still necessary to respectively provide the axial and circumferential strength and stiffness for the tube. Alternating between 0° and 90° plies – of course with reasonable number of plies in the same directions per alternation to avoid escalating manufacturing cost and time – could also be useful to separate 0° layers from each other and reduce their interaction and coupling upon fracture with the more deformable plies. To investigate these effects, a second composite tube with layup sequence [(90°10/0°10)3/(±45°)25] was considered, where 90° plies assemble the inner layer and ±45° layers build the outer jacket. The inner and outer diameters of the tube are 56.2 mm and 78.2 mm, respectively. The tube weighs about 3.4 kg/m.

sec.title: Step 2. Stiffness matching:
sec.p: The simulation technique is employed. The corresponding composite sandwich panel has the unit of width, the hypothetical core of 56.2 mm and a skin thickness of 11 mm laid up in [(90°10/0°10)3/(±45°)25] sequence. The total thickness of the composite sandwich panel is 78.2 mm that corresponds to the OD of the composite tube. The flexural stiffness of the corresponding composite sandwich panel is calculated to be 1327 N.m2.

As shown in Figure 6, the corresponding aluminum sandwich panel has the same hypothetical core with 56.2 mm thickness. In order to match the flexural stiffness of the composite panel, the aluminum panel should have a skin thickness of 8.9 mm that results in a total thickness of 74 mm. Upon proposed simulation methodology, the equivalent aluminum tube should have the same dimensions as the corresponding aluminum panel resulting in an inner diameter of 56.2 mm, an outer diameter of 74 mm, and the flexural stiffness of 68,758 N.m2. The aluminum tube weighs about 4.9 kg/m. Therefore, in contrast to its larger outer diameter, the composite tube, due to the lower density of Carbon AS4/PEKK, is about 30% lighter than the aluminum tube. Figure 6.
Application of the simulation technique for Example 2.

Using the nonclassical laminate theory and Equation (1), the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is calculated to be 71,038 N.m2, which shows about 1.6% difference with the simulation technique, 68,758 N.m2.

Table 3 shows the stiffness of the aluminum and composite tubes. It can be seen that the addition of the ±45° increases the thickness of the tube in comparison to that of the reference aluminum tube due to the lower stiffness of ±45° ply group (18 GPa vs. 70 GPa). Also the difference between using Equations (2) and (3) is less than 1%. Table 3.

sec.title: Step 3. Experimental results:
sec.p:
A thermoplastic composite tube of [(90°10/0°10)3/±45°25] layup sequence was made and subjected to three-point bending in a test set up with a span of 890 mm. A maximum load of 45 kN was applied over a fiber glass pad of 4 cm×8 cm on the top of the tube as a load distributor to avoid or at least delay potential local failures. Figure 7 shows the tube in three-point bending test at a final stage where local buckling and delamination at the mid-length has occurred. The external layer of the tube, which is made of ±45° plies, even though delaminated from the 0° ply group, has kept its integrity. Despite extensive fracture of internal 0° layers, the external jacket can easily deform up to 6% strain and therefore can hold the fractured internal plies in place. Knowing the fact that fracture normally commences in compression zone due to lower mechanical properties of the material, one can see that holding fractured layers in place causes the tube to hold some loads while broken fibers press against each other in a confined space between ±45° jacket and 90° liner. Figure 7.
Three-point bending test on the composite tube (Example 2).

Figure 8 shows the force versus axial strain at the mid-length of the tube measured at the bottom line. The force–strain curve for the reference aluminum tube is also shown. In the elastic limit, good agreement between the flexural stiffness of the composite tube with that of aluminum tube is observed. This indicates that the simulation technique with an acceptable error for many engineering applications calculated the bending stiffness of the composite tube. It is noteworthy that most of the available analytical solutions have the same order of error. However, there can be some explanation for this mismatch. For instance, the mechanical properties of the material are not the same in tension and compression, so the stiffness of the laminate varies from bottom part, which is in tension, toward the top part that is in compression. On the other hand, inspection of the tube revealed some manufacturing problems such as relatively large tolerance in layup angle and variation in overlapping of consequent tapes. Such problems, even if minor, need to be carefully addressed as the mechanical properties of the composites are highly fiber angle oriented. Finally, to some extent the error might be due to experimental work and loading technique. Figure 8.
Force-axial strain at the mid length of the tube at bottom (Example 2).

The force–strain curve of the composite tube is fairly linear up to where a maximum load of 45 kN is achieved, and then a sudden drop brings the load-carrying capacity of the tube to less than 35 kN. The test was continued until 3.5% strain was obtained. The tube was only supporting about 50% of the peak load at this position.

The second important issue is the structural strength and load-bearing capability. It can be seen that the composite tube in the elastic limit supports the same and even slightly higher loads than the aluminum tube. However, as the aluminum tube goes to plastic deformation, it carries more and more loads due to the strain hardening effect. In contrast, the composite tube after first major failure goes under more ply failures and sometimes delamination, which in turn brings down the load-bearing capability of the tube. For example, due to the variation in mechanical properties from tension to compression, the response of the upper and lower plies to a bending force would not be similar even at the same radial distance. This can cause ovalization, or as observed at the mid-length, delamination or local buckling of the layers with lower stiffness and higher deformation.

sec.title: Discussion

list-item.p: There is a sharp drop in the supported load at less than 1% strain. This sudden failure is consistent with the failure mode of the first tube and can be due to the fracture of 0° plies on the upper part of the tube under compression.

The radial stresses are positive at the top part of the tube, under the loading point. These positive radial stresses show that these layers tend to separate from each other, with the largest possibility happening between the outermost 90° layers from either the ±45° or 0° layers.

The presence of delamination between layers reduces the effective stiffness along the circumferential direction of the tube. This in turn can induce local buckling and lowering the flexural stiffness of the tube.

After the load drop, there is a holding range of about 2% strain at a lower load (between 30 and 35 kN). This hold is possible due to the jacket of ±45° plies on the outside. The relatively large deformation of these layers prevents the load drop to go completely to zero from the 45 kN peak. Without this buffer layer, the load would have dropped completely to zero as the case of the first tube.

It is foreseeable that a composite tube should be designed for slightly higher stiffness and relatively higher strength than the reference aluminum tube to assure both tubes demonstrate the same performance in three-point bending. The concern is more appealing for strength property as the load carrying capability of the composite tube deteriorates after peak load is achieved.

sec.p: By far the test objectives for the second composite tube were fulfilled. It was learnt that the ±45° jacket assists in holding the integrity of the tube and supporting some loads – even though at a lower value than the peak – while the tube experiences high deformation and strain. Nevertheless, the difference between the elastic stiffness of ±45° laminate and 0° laminate is quite considerable. As a result, upon fracture of the 0° plies, the rate of load transfer to the ±45° layer is too high for the latter to bear, and an undesirable sharp reduction in the load-bearing capability of the tube is inevitable. As such, the focus of the next attempt is not only to match the stiffness and deformation requirements but also to assure a gradual failure throughout the plies, which can result in holding the load at a level comparable to the peak load.

sec.title: Example 3: The optimized configuration
sec.p: Lessons learned from the first two examples were implemented in the design of a composite tube that matches stiffness, strength and deformability of an aluminum reference tube. As presented at the introduction of this article, a generic layup for such composite tubes was proposed.2 The last example of this article uses such layup.

sec.title: Step 1. Layup sequence:
sec.p: A composite tube with the following layup is considered:

Note that the 90° layers are spread out in order to separate the [±25°], [±30°], and [±45°] layers from each other. This is necessary to avoid the domino effect in fracture as was observed in the first two examples where the 0° plies were used. In fact 0° plies were not used for two reasons: low fracture strain and very high stiffness as compared to ±45° and other angle-ply laminates. However, still matching the stiffness is the first requirement for designing a composite tube, and one cannot solely use ±45° layer due to its considerably lower stiffness than aluminum. Therefore, in the above layup sequence, ±25° and ±30° plies are dominant. These laminates have elastic stiffness of 70 and 50 GPa, respectively, which are comparable to the Young’s modulus of aluminum. On the other hand, their average fracture strains are 1.8% and 2.5%, respectively that are noticeably more than that of 0° laminate. The gradual decrease in elastic stiffness and plodding increase in fracture strains of ±25° laminate toward ±45° laminate can provide potentials for gradual failure and higher deformation. It should be noted that strain requirements of each ply varies through the thickness of the tube. The plies closer to the neutral axis of the beam experience lower strain while the plies located at farther distance from the center are subject to higher strains when the tube is subjected to bending. Therefore, it can be seen that ±25° layer, which has lower fracture strain than ±30° layer, is located at an inner position in comparison to the ±30° layer that has lower stiffness. This is in contrast to the common understanding of designing composite beams where stronger and stiffer constituents are placed at the farthest distance from the neutral axis to obtain maximum flexural stiffness, <EI>. This approach was called strain-controlled design in comparison to common standard stress-stiffness-controlled design.1

sec.title: Step 2. Stiffness matching:
sec.p:
Similar to the previous examples, the simulation technique is used. The inner and outer diameters of the tube are 56.2 and 98.2 mm, respectively. The corresponding composite sandwich panel should have the unit of width, the hypothetical core of 56.2 mm and a skin thickness of 21 mm laid up in [90°30/±25°45/90°5/±30°20/90°5/±45°20] sequence. The total thickness of the composite sandwich panel is 98.2 mm that corresponds to the OD of the composite tube. The flexural stiffness of this panel is 3536 N.m2. The corresponding aluminum sandwich panel should have a similar stiffness and core dimensions. As shown in Figure 9, an aluminum skin of 18 mm is required, resulting in a total thickness of 92.2 mm for the aluminum panel. Based on the simulation technique, the equivalent aluminum tube will have inner and outer diameters of 56.2 and 92.2 mm, respectively. According to Equation (11), the flexural stiffness of the composite tube is equal to that of the equivalent aluminum tube (211,877 N.m2). Figure 9.
Application of the simulation technique for Example 3.

The weights for the aluminum and composite tubes are 11.3 and 7.5 kg/m, respectively. As such, though the composite tube is relatively thicker than the aluminum tube, due to the lower density of carbon AS4/PEKK in comparison to aluminum, the composite tube is still about 32% lighter. The weight saving promise is an important factor in aerospace applications such as the cross-tubes of helicopter landing gear.

Table 4 shows the stiffness values. It should be noticed that the difference between the stiffness values calculated by Equations (2) and (3) is about 1.2%. The difference between the non-classical laminate theory (Equation (1)) and the simulation technique (Equation (11)) is about 2%. Table 4.

sec.title: Step 3. Experimental results:
sec.p:
A tube of the above layup sequence was fabricated and tested in three-point bending. Figure 10 demonstrates the tube at a final stage where more than 2.5% strain has been achieved. The load carrying capability of the tube even at this final step is more than 125 kN, indicating that the tube after initial failure carries reasonable amount of load as compared to the peak value, which was 160 kN. Figure 10.
Bending test and high deformability of thermoplastic composite tube.

Figure 11 shows the force–strain curves for both aluminum and composite tubes. It can be seen that in the elastic range, the two curves show a good agreement. That is, the composite tube has similar flexural stiffness as its equivalent aluminum tube, and therefore, the use of the simulation technique for calculating the flexural stiffness of composite tubes is a valid approach. Figure 11.
Force–deflection curves for aluminum and third composite tubes.

It needs to be mentioned that the composite tube carries more loads at the peak than the aluminum tube. In fact, an aluminum tube can benefit from the plastic hardening effect and carry more loads after yield. However, a composite tube loses some strength upon the fracture of each ply. Therefore, a composite tube shall be designed to carry more loads at the peak to provide the same level of energy absorption as its equivalent aluminum tube.

As the load increases beyond the elastic limit, the aluminum tube deforms plastically. However, due to the plastic hardening effects, the load carried by the aluminum tube will slightly increase. For the composite tube, however, upon first major fracture, the load-bearing capacity of the tube will slightly decrease. This phenomenon was observed for the first and second composite tubes. After first major failure, the load-carrying capacity of the first composite tube was reduced by 100% while that of the second composite tube was sharp and abrupt but not more than 25%. For the third tube, however, the load reduction is about 15%, and more importantly, the load is reduced in a gradual fashion. Also the uniform curvature of the tube under loading in contrast to, the V shape of the second tube in Figure 7 should be noted.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p:
A simulation technique for calculating the flexural stiffness of composite tubes was presented. The technique considerably reduced the complexity of the analytical equations yet demonstrated the same order of accuracy as the complicated closed-form solutions. Table 5 compares the calculated flexural stiffness of the above examples via Equation (1) for the nonclassical laminate theory, Equation (11) for the simulation technique and Equation (12) for the experimental method by back-calculating the stiffness at 0.25% strain. It can be seen that the simulation technique can be successfully employed to calculate the flexural stiffness of composite tubes with any arbitrary layup sequence and number of plies. Example 1 presented a cross ply laminate with a small thickness. Example 2 illustrated the application of the technique for a composite tube with a medium thickness, and Example 3 demonstrated the use of the method for a thick composite tube. For all cases, the result error of the simulation technique is comparable to the analytical solution, yet the ease of analysis and time saving is impeccable. Meanwhile, a minimum of 30% weight saving was shown to be readily achievable in replacing an aluminum tube with a carbon fiber thermoplastic composite counterpart tube. Table 5.

It is noteworthy that despite the good agreement between the predicted flexural stiffnesses <EI> for composite and aluminum tubes as shown in Tables 2–4, Figures 5, 8, and 11 demonstrate slight differences in the slopes of the elastic parts of the experimental load–strain curves for the composite and aluminum designs. Many parameters beyond what discussed here might be responsible for such differences. For example, the current simulation methodology is based on pure bending assumption. However, in Derisi et al.2,3 it was found that for composite tubes, the adjacent layers have complex interactions in three-point bending configuration, which is simply not the case for an aluminum structure. This might also be due to the effects of shear deformation, which would not show up in the predicted <EI> values. However, these effects might at least partially explain the differences in the slopes of the experimental load–strain curves.

Nevertheless, the three examples show that in order to develop a thick composite tube that can exhibit high stiffness, high strength, and good deformation, the following considerations are beneficial or necessary:
Thermoplastic composite can be employed. It is obvious that higher toughness and deformability of thermoplastic polymers contribute to composite tube deformability.
Layup sequence should have layers with small strain limit on the inside and layers with high strain limit on the outside. This results in having the higher strength and stiffness layers close to the beam neutral axis, which is in contrast to the common practice of sandwich beams, where layers with higher strength and stiffness are placed at the farthest distance. This technique is essential for composite tubes to assure that no layer passes its critical fracture strain (Figure 1). The technique is called strain-controlled design in contrast to the normal stiffness-controlled approach.
Layers with high strain limit should be separated away from layers with small strain limit to reduce interaction of adjacent layers and domino effects in fracture. This can be done by placing 90° layers in between.
Stiffness calculation can be done using the simulation technique with an acceptable accuracy for many engineering applications yet with a considerable ease in analysis.
Optimization of the stacking sequence for weight saving purposes should be done within the framework provided for large deformation consideration. For example, including 0° layers even though reduces the weight of the composite tube limits its deformability and therefore should be avoided.
Three-dimensional stress analysis should be carried out to determine the stress distribution. Particular attention should be given to the occurrence of positive radial stresses since these can give rise to delamination which can lead to early failure by buckling.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A procedure for the development of composite tubes that can exhibit high strength, high stiffness, and large deformation for primary load-bearing structures was presented. A novel methodology for calculating the flexural stiffness of composite tubes via a simulation technique was established. Three composite tubes were designed and tested to validate the procedure. Experimental results from these three tubes show that the procedure is viable. A minimum of 30% weight saving was shown to be achievable by the use of carbon fiber thermoplastic composites instead of aluminum. Future work will involve optimization of the layup sequence for minimizing the weight and reducing the development of positive radial stresses.
